thread.title: Keur, James spark CSU men’s golf to second-place finish
thread.title_full: Keur, James spark CSU men’s golf to second-place finish

title: Keur, James spark CSU men’s golf to second-place finish
text: Keur, James spark CSU men’s golf to second-place finish Staff reports Facebook @postandcourier Oct 26 2015 12:52 am CAMDEN — Charleston Southern sophomore R.J. Keur had five birdies to put together a 3-under 67 and junior Austin James had four in his round of 68 as the Buccaneers shot the low round of the day to seize second at the Camden Collegiate Invitational, which wrapped up on Sunday at Camden Country Club. CSU fired a 279 — six strokes lower than any other score in the field — to climb two spots, finishing only behind No. 25 and host South Carolina. James finished tied for sixth, seven strokes back. He finished the weekend with two rounds in the 60s. The Gamecocks finished at 2-under, while the Bucs were 23-over. Furman (+25), USC Aiken (+30) and Wofford (+34) rounded out the top five. The College of Charleston women’s golf team completed its first day of competition at the Palmetto Intercollegiate on Turtle Point Golf Course at Kiawah Island, with Mary Chandler Bryan leading the way for the Cougars at 2-under par. Bryan scored a 70 on the day, well below the course average of 75.75. She stands tied for third overall individually, with teammate Laura Fuenfstueck close on her heels at 1 under, tied for 11th. The Cougars were 11-over par, placing them in a tie for 13th headed into Monday. Campbell, the No. 48-ranked team in the country, leads the pack at two under par, with Kennesaw State second. Charleston Southern sophomore Hayley McNeill is tied for 23rd and the Buccaneers are 16th. MeNeill put together a 1-over 73 to lead CSU, which fired a 306 (+18) as a team and is 20 shots back in the 20-team field which features a number of nationally ranked programs. The College of Charleston men’s team is eighth after the first day of play at The Intercollegiate at The Grove hosted by Middle Tennessee State at The Grove Golf Club located outside of Nashville. Senior John Jonas paced the Cougars with an opening-round 74 with two birdies. He is tied for 17th (+2), while junior William Rainey is tied for 19th (+3). Volleyball College of Charleston could not find its rhythm, falling to Hofstra 3-0 (25-20, 25-20, 25-19) in Hempstead, N.Y. Both teams came out swinging in the first set. The Cougars hit .333 but couldn’t overcome Hofstra’s attack, which hit at a .405 clip. Charleston struggled with 20 attack errors while the Pride committed just 12. Allison Beckman finished the match with 32 assists for C of C, while Kayla Tronick and Krissy Mummey ended with three blocks each. Keywords
